urls.title: Grant
urls.description: There are six words you will see again and again over the coming days as so many of us try to make sense of the senseless: He was the best of us. Grant Wahl was that. As a person, he was ceaselessly kind. As a reporter, he was bursting with courage and an unerring sense of right and wrong. As a writer, he was so deeply alive. And as a friend, mostly as a friend, he was undyingly devoted and loyal. The best of us. Every way.

data.text: Grant - by Joe Posnanski - JoeBlogs https://t.co/Qhc6KIU8ih

urls.title: Grant Wahl, renowned soccer journalist, dies at Qatar World Cup
urls.description: The circumstances of Wahl's death were unclear.

urls.title: LeBron James and Billie Jean King lead tributes to American journalist Grant Wahl | CNN
urls.description: The death of prominent journalist Grant Wahl at the World Cup in Qatar has led to an outpouring of shock and grief across the sports world, with NBA star LeBron James and tennis great Billie Jean King leading the tributes to the American.

data.text: https://t.co/pkH0Pm9weQ

urls.title: Prominent Soccer Journalist Grant Wahl, 48, Dies While Covering World Cup in Qatar
urls.description: Wahl, who chronicled men’s and women’s soccer in the U.S. for more than two decades, collapsed during the Argentina-Netherlands match.

data.text: Journalist Grant Wahl, one of the most prominent chroniclers of American soccer over more than 20 years and a longtime writer for Sports Illustrated, died on Friday night while covering the World Cup in Qatar. He was 49. https://t.co/6bbYSGM6MB

urls.title: American journalist Grant Wahl dies at Qatar World Cup | CNN
urls.description: American journalist Grant Wahl has died in Qatar while covering the World Cup, US Soccer said in a statement.

data.text: https://t.co/f6qVnax22O

urls.title: Soccer Journalist Dies at World Cup After Collapsing at Argentina Game
urls.description: Grant Wahl, who in his career covered soccer for Sports Illustrated, Fox Sports and CBS, was in Qatar for his eighth World Cup.

data.text:
18/ A very thin silver lining:

Medicaid will cover COVID treatment at least through early 2024.

So at least in some states, low-income populations will still have access to Paxlovid & other COVID treatments. 

https://t.co/Qyqit7s4H8

17/ The US government purchased 20M courses of Paxlovid.

So far, we've used less than 1/3 of that supply.

If there's left-over supply, it could set aside for seniors & people without insurance.

But we don't know how much will be left after this winter.

16/ Black & Hispanic patients with COVID are much less likely to receive Paxlovid that White people.

And that gap is likely to widen when the US government stops providing it for free.

15/ We've already seen disparities in access to Paxlovid & monoclonal antibodies to treat COVID.

You need someone to prescribe COVID treatment to you even if it's free for now.
14/ If getting Paxlovid costs people money, some people will go without, which means more will end up in the hospital or dead.

13/ This means that uninsured people & seniors, i.e. those at the highest risk for COVID & least able to pay for COVID treatments, may have to pay out-of-pocket full price.

90% of COVID deaths are now among people 65+.

12/ The situation is more complicated when it comes to people 65+.

If Paxlovid remains under an emergency use authorization & hasn't yet been granted full approval by the FDA when the PHE ends, Medicare Part D won't cover it.
11/ Private health insurance will provide some coverage for COVID treatments, but people will still need to pay co-pays... and in some cases... may still be on the hook for the whole cost.
10/ When the USG stops purchasing COVID treatments like Paxlovid for Americans, people will get COVID treatments the same way they get their inhalers or insulin or blood pressure meds.

9/ The US government purchased 20M courses of Paxlovid at $530 per course.

As with vaccines, the price per course will shoot up once the US government is no longer buying it to give to the American people for free.

8/ The USG has also run out of money to buy more COVID treatments like Paxlovid.

Paxlovid reduces the risk of hospitalization & death, regardless of whether or not you're vaccinated.

Paxlovid may also reduce the risk of long COVID.

7/ The Biden administration has proposed creating a new Vaccines for Adults program, modeled after the Vaccines for Children program, which vaccinates uninsured kids.

But Congress hasn't provided funding for this plan.

6/ Most people with insurance will still have free access to COVID vaccines, but private insurance premiums are likely to go up as a result.

And uninsured people will likely be priced out of COVID vaccinations.

5/ And it's not just the cost of the vaccine that's going to shoot up.

You also need to add the cost of vaccine administration (~$25-40 per dose) + the fee for a doctor's visit.

4/ Why will vaccine prices shoot up?

Pfizer & Moderna will negotiate prices with insurance companies & healthcare systems, not with the USG.

Insurance companies & healthcare systems won't have the same bulk purchasing power of the USG to negotiate lower prices.

3/ The US government bought 1.2B doses of Pfizer & Moderna COVID vaccines for ~$20 per dose.

Once vaccine purchases move to the commercial market (i.e. USG is no longer the buyer), both Pfizer & Moderna are expected to raise their prices to ~$100 per dose.

2/ Last month, the Biden administration asked Congress for $2.5B to buy COVID vaccines & treatments for people who won't be able to afford them through the regular healthcare system.

Without $$$ from Congress, the administration can't buy more.

But Congress turned a deaf ear.

urls.title: Implications of commercializing COVID-19 vaccines, treatments
urls.description: The U.S. government could stop paying for COVID-19 vaccines and treatments, which would shift the burden to the commercial market. Dr. Céline Gounder, a CBS News contributor and editor at large for Kaiser Health News, discussed the impact of potentially commercializing coronavirus vaccines and treatments.

Covid-19 Isn’t a Pandemic of the Unvaccinated Anymore

by @dwallacewells 

It's a pandemic of the old.

Ageism makes it easier to pretend the pandemic is over.

Yet COVID is now the 3rd leading cause of death in the US. https://t.co/C3tGYxmHhK

Many good lessons for health  (not just global health) journalists here.👇🏾

This one in particular resonated with me & my reactions to how the 2014-15 Ebola epidemic was covered, or to quote @hofrench: "Africa without Africans."
https://t.co/OlrNOTY8Ws https://t.co/ygeZganOqp https://t.co/jpOKdUF7Cf

COVID hospitalizations🏥 are up⬆️27% nationwide.

Rates are especially high among 70+ year-olds.

See the top purple🟣 line in the graph on the right.👇🏾

If you're 50+🧓🏻👴🏿, immunocompromised, or pregnant🫄🏼 & haven't gotten your COVID booster💉 this fall, NOW is the time. https://t.co/w7wXdUYt5x
@RealCedricDark divide by 2

6/ Much of the US blood🩸 supply is donated at workplace blood donation drives.

With fewer people going into the office since the start of the COVID pandemic, less blood is being donated.

5/ This is an important development because barring gay & bisexual🏳️‍🌈 men is unscientific & stigmatizing.

And it will help alleviate the nation's blood🩸 shortages.

4/ The good news: yes!

Gay & bisexual🏳️‍🌈 men who reported no new sexual partners in the past 3 months can safely donate blood🩸.

Based on this data, the @US_FDA will likely open up blood donation to gay & bisexual men.

3/ But HIV tests🧪today are highly sensitive & turn positive within 10d of exposure.

3 of the nation's biggest blood🩸centers studied whether blood donation could be safely opened up to gay & bisexual🏳️‍🌈 men by pairing individual risk assessment questionnaires with HIV testing.

2/ It may have made sense to restrict blood🩸 donations by gay & bisexual🏳️‍🌈 men early in the HIV/AIDS pandemic when HIV tests🧪 were less sensitive & it took longer from the time of exposure until tests turned positive (the window period).

urls.title: Changes in population immunity against infection and severe disease from SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variants in the United States between December 2021 and November 2022
urls.description: Importance: While a substantial fraction of the US population was infected with SARS-CoV-2 during December 2021-February 2022, the subsequent evolution of population immunity against SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variants reflects the competing influences of waning protection over time and acquisition or restoration of immunity through additional infections and vaccinations. Objective: To estimate changes in population immunity against infection and severe disease due to circulating SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variants in the United States from December 2021 to November 2022, and to quantify the protection against a potential 2022-2023 winter SARS-CoV-2 wave. Design, setting, participants: Bayesian evidence synthesis of reported COVID-19 data (diagnoses, hospitalizations), vaccinations, and waning patterns for vaccine- and infection-acquired immunity, using a mathematical model of COVID-19 natural history. Main Outcomes and Measures: Population immunity against infection and severe disease from SARS-CoV-2

12/ To reduce COVID deaths, we should encourage & support:
🔹boosting people 50+ (& immunocompromised people & pregnant women)
🔹mask-wearing in indoor public places
🔹testing
🔹staying home & away from others when sick

11/ Here's what I make of this data:

~90% of COVID deaths are now among 65+.

The elderly respond less well to COVID vaccination.

COVID vaccinations are necessary but not sufficient to protect the elderly from COVID.

10/ Much anti-vaxxer rhetoric stems from cognitive biases.

Base rate bias is but one.

Other common cognitive biases include:
🔹confirmation bias (e.g. cherry-picking data)
🔹reading too much into coincidences
🔹congruence bias (not considering alternate hypotheses)

9/ Why are the COVID vaccines less protective among 80+ year-olds than among 65-79 year-olds?

80+ year-olds have weaker immune systems.

Just like the rest of your body, your immune system ages & functions less well with age, too.

8/ Now let's drill down on the elderly:

65-79 year-olds are 8x more likely to die from COVID if they are unvaccinated than if they are vaccinated.

80+ year-olds are ~3.8x more likely to die from COVID if they are unvaccinated than if they are vaccinated.

Vaccines work! https://t.co/vQd991iNL7

data.text:
4/ There are alternatives to colonoscopies.

An advantage of a colonoscopy is that if there's an abnormality, it can be biopsied & removed immediately during the same procedure.

https://t.co/FcMO2qtghA https://t.co/hGJk8POff5

3/ While most commonly diagnosed among people 65-74, 10% of new colorectal cancer cases occur in people under 50.

The rates of colorectal cancer in adults 40-49 ⬆️by ~15% between 2000 and 2016.

Almost 1/3 of Americans aren't up to date with their colorectal cancer screening.

2/ Don't be afraid of getting a colonoscopy.

Colorectal cancer is the 3rd leading cause of cancer death for both men & women.

Over 50K people die from colorectal cancer every year. https://t.co/Ruj6wEoqF9

1/ I had my first screening colonoscopy today (yipee 45)!

The good news: it was normal.

It wasn't painful, and I got to take a nap😴 in the middle of the day. It doesn't get much better than that!

And the Thanksgiving🦃🍂 feast tomorrow is a nice reward. https://t.co/KDuPn7JKBm

13/ This study did not look at & cannot answer whether it made sense to update the boosters.

This study also does not provide the baseline risks for symptomatic COVID in each group, only comparative risks (& hence the educated guesses).

12/ This study wasn't designed to compare the vaccine effectiveness of a bivalent booster

VERSUS

the vaccine effectiveness of a monovalent booster

in protecting against symptomatic COVID

when BA.4/BA.5 were dominant.

11/ To show it was worthwhile to roll out updated boosters (rather than use the original monovalent vaccine as a booster), the appropriate comparison should have been:

2+ shots of monovalent vaccine + monovalent booster

VERSUS

2+ shots of monovalent vaccine + bivalent booster

10/ If someone who got 2+ doses of the original vaccine was 50% (another educated guess) likely to get symptomatic COVID,

someone who got 2+ doses of the original vaccine + 1 updated bivalent booster was ~25-35% likely to get symptomatic COVID,

when BA.4/BA.5 were dominant.

9/ Relative vaccine effectiveness
= [(risk of infection among 2+ mono) – (risk of infection among 2+ mono + 1 bi)]
/ (risk of infection among 2+ mono)
= ~30-50%

8/  The second comparison:

Table 3:
protection against symptomatic infection from BA.4/BA.5
with 2+ doses of the original vaccine + 1 updated bivalent booster
VERSUS
2+ doses of the original vaccine https://t.co/piPL6UrKoH

7/ If an unvaccinated person was 80% (an educated guess) likely to get COVID,

a vaccinated & bivalent-boosted person was ~40-60% likely to get COVID

when BA.4/BA.5 were dominant.

6/ Absolute vaccine effectiveness
= (risk of infection among unvaccinated) – (risk of infection among vaccinated)
= ~20-40%

5/ The study makes two different comparisons:

Table 2:
protection against symptomatic infection from BA.4/BA.5
with 2+ doses of the original vaccine + 1 updated bivalent booster
VERSUS
no vaccine https://t.co/rBzd1revdF

urls.title: New Covid boosters work better against infection than previous shots, CDC finds
urls.description: The omicron booster shots performed better in preventing infections in all adult age groups, with more protection for people who waited longer to get them.

data.text:
4/ What are the dominant variants in the US now? BQ.1, BQ.1.1, BF.1, BN.1, which are even more immune evasive than BA.4/5.

https://t.co/AttUvQWqi5
by @NBCNews' @BerkeleyJr https://t.co/Vt5Wii4nKE

3/ But there’s more to the story for people interested in the science.

For one thing, this study looked at protection against symptomatic infection with BA.4/BA.5.

2/ For the average person, that’s all you need to know.

The only boosters available now are the updated bivalent boosters.

If you’re 50+ or immunocompromised or pregnant, get a COVID booster ASAP.

the updated boosters will provide additional protection

10/ That doesn't mean it would have been better to give them immunity to RSV via infection sooner.

If anything, they would have been younger & might have gotten even sicker.

The problem is that we're not flattening the curve to spread out cases & hospitalizations over time.

9/ The transmission of viral respiratory infections was suppressed by mask-wearing & social distancing during the first 2 years of the pandemic.

Kids born during that time haven't been exposed to RSV.

Now they're getting exposed all at once, creating a big strain on hospitals.

8/ The reason we vaccinate💉 is to give people immunity against infectious diseases WITHOUT running the RISK of actually contracting those infectious diseases.

There's a vaccine for flu.

There's a vaccine for COVID.

In a couple more years, we'll also have a vaccine for RSV.

7/ Masks protect against COVID, the flu, & RSV.

Masks don't give you COVID.

Masks don't cause RSV.

If Paxlovid remains under an emergency use authorization & hasn't yet been granted full approval by the FDA when the PHE ends, Medicare Part D won't cover it.
11/ Private health insurance will provide some coverage for COVID treatments, but people will still need to pay co-pays... and in some cases... may still be on the hook for the whole cost.
10/ When the USG stops purchasing COVID treatments like Paxlovid for Americans, people will get COVID treatments the same way they get their inhalers or insulin or blood pressure meds.

9/ The US government purchased 20M courses of Paxlovid at $530 per course.

As with vaccines, the price per course will shoot up once the US government is no longer buying it to give to the American people for free.

8/ The USG has also run out of money to buy more COVID treatments like Paxlovid.

Paxlovid reduces the risk of hospitalization & death, regardless of whether or not you're vaccinated.

Paxlovid may also reduce the risk of long COVID.

7/ The Biden administration has proposed creating a new Vaccines for Adults program, modeled after the Vaccines for Children program, which vaccinates uninsured kids.

But Congress hasn't provided funding for this plan.

6/ Most people with insurance will still have free access to COVID vaccines, but private insurance premiums are likely to go up as a result.

And uninsured people will likely be priced out of COVID vaccinations.

5/ And it's not just the cost of the vaccine that's going to shoot up.

You also need to add the cost of vaccine administration (~$25-40 per dose) + the fee for a doctor's visit.

4/ Why will vaccine prices shoot up?

Pfizer & Moderna will negotiate prices with insurance companies & healthcare systems, not with the USG.

Insurance companies & healthcare systems won't have the same bulk purchasing power of the USG to negotiate lower prices.

3/ The US government bought 1.2B doses of Pfizer & Moderna COVID vaccines for ~$20 per dose.

Once vaccine purchases move to the commercial market (i.e. USG is no longer the buyer), both Pfizer & Moderna are expected to raise their prices to ~$100 per dose.

2/ Last month, the Biden administration asked Congress for $2.5B to buy COVID vaccines & treatments for people who won't be able to afford them through the regular healthcare system.

Without $$$ from Congress, the administration can't buy more.

But Congress turned a deaf ear.

urls.title: Changes in population immunity against infection and severe disease from SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variants in the United States between December 2021 and November 2022
urls.description: Importance: While a substantial fraction of the US population was infected with SARS-CoV-2 during December 2021-February 2022, the subsequent evolution of population immunity against SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variants reflects the competing influences of waning protection over time and acquisition or restoration of immunity through additional infections and vaccinations. Objective: To estimate changes in population immunity against infection and severe disease due to circulating SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variants in the United States from December 2021 to November 2022, and to quantify the protection against a potential 2022-2023 winter SARS-CoV-2 wave. Design, setting, participants: Bayesian evidence synthesis of reported COVID-19 data (diagnoses, hospitalizations), vaccinations, and waning patterns for vaccine- and infection-acquired immunity, using a mathematical model of COVID-19 natural history. Main Outcomes and Measures: Population immunity against infection and severe disease from SARS-CoV-2

11/ Here's what I make of this data:

10/ Much anti-vaxxer rhetoric stems from cognitive biases.

Base rate bias is but one.

Other common cognitive biases include:
🔹confirmation bias (e.g. cherry-picking data)
🔹reading too much into coincidences
🔹congruence bias (not considering alternate hypotheses)

9/ Why are the COVID vaccines less protective among 80+ year-olds than among 65-79 year-olds?

80+ year-olds have weaker immune systems.

Just like the rest of your body, your immune system ages & functions less well with age, too.

8/ Now let's drill down on the elderly:

65-79 year-olds are 8x more likely to die from COVID if they are unvaccinated than if they are vaccinated.

80+ year-olds are ~3.8x more likely to die from COVID if they are unvaccinated than if they are vaccinated.
